docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 13 Recommendations that will probably result in a moratorium on most medical research conducted in prisons in the United States were voted today by the National Commission for the Protection of Human Subjects of Biomedical and Behavioral Research.

headline.main: Panel's Proposals May Curtail Medical Experiments in Prisons

docs.abstract: comm votes on recommendations to curtail most med research conducted in US prisons; recommendations may affect behavior modification experiments (M)

byline.original: By HAROLD M. SCHMECK Jr. Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON Ten years ago this month a relatively obscure Connecticut lawyer was haunting the halls of Congress, lobbying for a bill he passionately supported. On June 24, 1966, the Senate overrode the objections of one of the most powerful segments of American industry and passed legislation requiring the Federal Government to set automobile safety standards.

headline.main: Nader Today: His Main Interest Is in Getting Others Organized

docs.abstract: Article on Ralph Nader as consumer advocate, on areas of consumerism in which he is involved and orgns he has formed to help him; illus (L)
